Technical Assistance Report
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Project Number: 44152 
Regional — Capacity Development Technical Assistance (R-CDTA) 
September 2010 
 
 
 
Updating and Improving the Social Protection Index  
(Cofinanced by the Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge 
Partnership Fund)

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  HIES  –  household income and expenditure survey 
  ILO  –  International Labour Organization 
  OECD  –  Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development 
  RSGS  –  Poverty Reduction, Gender and Social Development Division 
  SPI  –  social protection index 
  TA   –  technical assistance

Vice-President  U. Schaefer-Preuss, Knowledge Management and Sustainable 
Development 
Director General  X. Yao, Regional and Sustainable Development Department (RSDD) 
Director  B. Édes, Poverty Reduction, Gender, and Social Development Division, 
RSDD 
   
Team leader  S. W. Handayani, Senior Social Development Specialist, RSDD 
Team members  B. Babajanian, Social Development Specialist, RSDD 
P. Lubag, Operations Assistant, RSDD  
H. Manzano-Guerzon, Senior Operations Assistant, RSDD 
M. Principe, Social Development Officer, RSDD 
 
 
 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) approved its Social Protection Strategy in 2001.1 
The strategy supports ADB’s developing member countries (DMCs) in Asia and the Pacific in 
their efforts to reduce poverty and vulnerability and provide their populations with effective social 
protection. The social protection index (SPI) was developed for 31 countries in Asia and the 
Pacific under two regional technical assistance (TA) projects that were implemented in 2003 
and 2006.2 The index summarizes the extent of social protection in the countries, giving ADB 
and the DMCs better quantitative and qualitative information on social protection activities and 
an internationally comparable database of social protection expenditures, coverage, distribution, 
and impact. 
 
2.  The SPI has been used in a variety of academic and other publications on social and 
economic development in Asia and the Pacific. It has been used by ADB’s partner organizations, 
including  the  Organisation  for  Economic  Co-operation  and  Development  (OECD)  and  the 
International Labour Organization (ILO), in assessing social protection in the region. ADB has 
also  relied  on  the  social  protection  data  and  indices  in  its  analytical  work  and  country 
partnership strategies. But weak ownership of the SPI among the DMCs and the low institutional 
capacity of their line ministries have held back DMC policy makers from using the index more 
fully in analyzing, monitoring, and evaluating policies, programs, and projects. 
 
3.  The proposed TA will build on the SPI work done under the earlier TA, and will introduce 
other components and institutional arrangements to sustain the effective use of the social 
protection indicators in policy analysis and formulation in the DMCs. The main objective will be 
to strengthen social protection in the DMCs by updating and improving the SPI and building the 
capacity of the DMCs to measure, monitor, and analyze social protection systematically. The 
design and monitoring framework for the TA is presented in Appendix 1.3 
II.  ISSUES 
4.  Most DMCs in Asia and the Pacific have social protection programs and policies, and 
many have expanded their social protection systems in recent years. But accessible social 
protection is still an important policy imperative. Most DMCs urgently need to reform, strengthen, 
and expand their social protection programs and policies to protect their populations and make 
them less vulnerable to risk. 
 
 5.  Social  protection  involves  interventions  that  provide  livelihood  security  to  poor  and 
vulnerable individuals to help them prevent, reduce, or cope with economic, social, climatic, and 
security risks. This study narrowly defines social protection as referring to two policy subsets: 
social assistance (noncontributory cash or in-kind transfers and welfare services) and social 
insurance  (contributory  schemes  that  reduce  risks  associated  with  old  age,  disability, 
unemployment, sickness, etc.). Social protection policies and programs vary between countries 
because of their different needs, cultures, institutions, and available resources. 
 
                                                 
1  ADB. 2003. Social Protection. Manila (adopted in 2001).   
2  ADB.  2003.  Technical  Assistance  for  Social  Protection  Index  for  Committed  Poverty  Reduction.  Manila 
(TA 6120-REG); ADB. 2006. Technical Assistance for Scaling Up of the Social Protection Index for Committed 
Poverty Reduction. Manila (TA 6308-REG). 
3  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 23 August 2010.

2   
6.  Systematic and rigorous monitoring and impact assessment of social protection is a 
prerequisite for improving the existing systems and developing new policies and programs. Most 
DMCs have limited institutional and technical capacity to carry out regular monitoring and 
evaluation, make rigorous diagnostic assessments of impact, and analyze social protection 
policy. Their development plans have yet to include the measurement of social protection and 
the analysis of social protection policy and issues. The DMCs must also take ownership of their 
social protection data to track progress continuously and systematically.  
 
7.  The proposed TA can help fill the need by producing data and information on social 
protection in the 31 DMCs and building the capacity of the DMCs to collect and analyze social 
protection data regularly. The TA will build on the SPI work done under earlier ADB TA  projects 
(footnote 2) and will address the lessons from those projects. In particular, the TA projects 
showed that: (i) SPI can be an effective tool for cross-country comparisons if the SPI rankings 
are carefully analyzed and interpreted; (ii) the methods used in formulating the index need to be 
refined;  and  (iii) the  DMCs  need  further  capacity  building  to  monitor  and  analyze  social 
protection effectively.  
 
8.  In July 2010, ADB held a technical meeting with representatives of OECD, ILO, and six 
DMCs4 to discuss the methods, indicators, and implementation arrangements for the proposed 
TA. The participants recommended specific improvements in the methods and the formula for 
generating the SPI, and in the design and implementation arrangements for the TA. These 
recommendations will be followed. 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
9.  The TA will strengthen the capacity of the participating DMCs to measure and monitor 
social protection by (i) developing an improved framework and methods for measuring and 
monitoring social protection; (ii) generating and updating the SPI, the SPI database, and social 
protection assessments; and (iii) building capacity of the DMCs to measure and monitor social 
protection.  
 
10.  The improved methods and framework for SPI data collection and analysis will be used 
in updating the SPI, the database, and the assessments of country social protection systems. 
These in turn will enable the tracking of social protection and thereby institutionalize social 
protection measurement and monitoring in the DMCs. 
 
11.  The updated SPI will provide a summary measurement of the effectiveness of social 
protection in 31 countries in Asia and the Pacific in supporting their citizens, including those 
living below the poverty line. The SPI will help monitor changes in the provision of social 
protection over time and will facilitate international comparisons. Important evidence of social 
protection  activities  in  the  DMCs  will  be  collected.  This  will  include  (i) statistical  data  and 
indicators,  such  as  expenditure,  coverage,  and  distribution  (SPI  database);  and  (ii) a 
comprehensive review of country social protection programs and policies (country reports).  
 
12.  The TA will build the capacity of DMCs by (i) providing them with a social protection 
information  base,  including  an  SPI  database  and  social  protection  assessments;  and 
(ii) generating  survey  instruments  and  methods  that  the  DMCs  can  use  in  updating  and 
maintaining the SPI database. The indicators in the SPI database and the evidence collected for 
                                                 
4  Representatives of national statistics offices of Armenia, Bangladesh, Indonesia, Mongolia, the Philippines, and 
Viet Nam participated in the meeting.

3
social  protection  assessments  are  expected  to  contribute  to  national  policy  analysis  and 
planning. In particular, the DMCs can use them in (i) making diagnostic evaluations of social 
protection, (ii) defining social protection targets, and (iii) modifying policies and programs and 
developing  new  ones.  The  very  process  of  gathering  information  for  the  SPI  and  then 
disseminating the results can increase awareness of the importance of social protection. The TA 
will support three selected DMCs in integrating social protection monitoring into their household 
income and expenditure surveys (HIESs) and build their capacity to use the data in policy 
analysis and planning.5 
 
13.  In developing the SPI and its database, the TA will use gender-disaggregated indicators 
where  possible.  The  extent  to  which  women  benefit  from  social  protection  can  thus  be 
monitored and gender concerns can be integrated into social protection policies and programs. 
 
14.  The  TA  will  bring  together  development  partners  to  strengthen  social  protection  in 
developing countries. ADB has prepared a collaboration plan with the OECD/Korea Policy 
Centre and ILO; these institutions are expected to help institutionalize the SPI in the Asia and 
the Pacific region, where its coverage is now limited. Through the TA, the development partners 
will have improved quantitative and qualitative information on social protection activities, and an 
internationally comparable database, at their disposal. 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
15.  The impact of the TA will be the expansion of social protection systems to cover the poor 
and the vulnerable in Asia and the Pacific. Its outcome will be DMCs with improved capacity to 
monitor and measure social protection, assess its effectiveness over time, determine its relative 
strengths and weaknesses, and identify improvements.  
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
16.  To  achieve  the  desired  outcome,  the  TA  will  have  three  major  components:  (i) the 
compilation and analysis of data on social protection programs (social insurance and social 
assistance) to develop and update the SPI; (ii) the capacity development of three selected 
DMCs and the training of government agencies to develop and analyze the SPI; and (iii) the 
management of knowledge products and the dissemination of information. 
1.  Component 1: Collection of Data on Social Protection Programs and 
Preparation of Country Reports  
17.  The TA will fund analytical work to improve the methods of defining, implementing, and 
measuring social protection, and to develop an integrated framework for data collection. The 
improved methods and data collection framework will be used in gathering data and reviewing 
social protection programs and policies in 31 countries in Asia and the Pacific. The SPI will be 
computed, the social protection rankings updated, and social protection assessments (country 
reports) produced on the basis of the data and information gathered.  
 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
 members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.  
                                                 
5  Armenia, Indonesia, and Sri Lanka.

4   
2.  Component 2: Capacity Development for Selected DMCs 
18.  The TA will support three selected DMCs6 in integrating social protection monitoring into 
their HIESs). In particular, ADB will help train enumerators and supervisors, and will offer 
technical advice on the preparation of survey instruments and methods for incorporating the 
module into the HIES.7 A memorandum of agreement specifying the activities under this TA, 
and the financial and technical support from ADB, will be drawn up with the national statistical 
offices of the three selected DMCs.  
3.  Component 3: Management of Knowledge Products and Dissemination of 
Information  
19.  The social protection indices, together with the SPI handbook or manual describing the 
methods, data collection techniques, survey instruments, and other relevant materials, will be 
published  in  a  two-volume  book  and  a  compact  disc  (SPI  report).  A  social  protection 
assessment report (country report) will be published for each country.  
 
20.  Other  important  knowledge  products  from  the  TA,  including  the  SPI  database, 
methodological  tools,  and  reporting  templates  for  the  social  protection  assessments,  are 
expected to be used by the participating countries in measuring and monitoring social protection. 
These knowledge products will be stored and maintained by the line agencies responsible for 
the SPI exercise. 
 
21.  The  TA  will  produce  analytical  reports  (policy  papers)  that  provide  cross-country 
comparisons of social protection expenditure, coverage, and distribution in Asia and the Pacific; 
assess the poverty impact of social protection in low-income DMCs; and show the relevance of 
household surveys in measuring and monitoring social protection. 
 
22.  The consolidated SPI report, the country reports, and the policy papers will be circulated 
among  policy  makers  and  other  important  stakeholders  in  all  participating  DMCs.  The 
participating countries, development partners, and civil society organizations will be invited to 
discuss the SPI outcomes in workshops and learning events. Experts from ADB, ILO, and 
OECD/Korea Policy Centre will contribute to the information dissemination. The learning and 
good practices will be disseminated through publications on the ADB social protection, ILO 
Social  Security  Inquiry,  and  OECD  websites.  A  communications  plan  for  the  effective 
dissemination of knowledge generated under the TA will be drafted. 
C.  Cost and Financing 
23.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,300,000 equivalent, of which $500,000 equivalent will be 
financed on a grant basis by the Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF–other sources), and 
$500,000 equivalent will be financed on a grant basis by the Republic of Korea e-Asia and 
Knowledge Partnership Fund and administered by ADB. A detailed cost estimate is presented in 
Appendix 2. The ILO, the OECD/Korea Policy Centre, and the participating DMCs will finance 
the remaining $300,000 equivalent with in-kind contributions.  
                                                 
6  The possible integration of a social protection module in the HIES was the subject of preliminary discussions with 
the national statistics offices of Armenia, Indonesia, and Sri Lanka. The three DMCs were chosen on the basis of 
the capacity of their statistics offices to conduct a regular HIES. A memorandum of agreement will be prepared at 
the start of the TA. 
7  A no-objection letter from the 31 countries will be sought before the TA is implemented in any particular country.

5
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
24.  The TA will be implemented over 24 months (September 2010–September 2012). ADB 
will be the executing agency, and the Poverty Reduction, Gender, and Social Development 
Division (RSGS) of ADB’s Regional and Sustainable Development Department will be the focal 
point for the overall management and monitoring of the TA activities. Throughout the TA period, 
RSGS will consult closely with the regional departments and coordinate with the Economics and 
Research Department. Progress and output updates will be posted regularly on ADB’s social 
development website with links to social protection websites.  
 
25.  The  TA  will  finance  65.5  person-months  of  consulting  services  (8.5  person-months 
international,  57  person-months  national).  The  consultants  will  be  selected  and  hired 
individually, according to ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from 
time to time). The terms of reference for the consultants are in Appendix 3.  
 
26.  ADB, ILO, and the OECD have agreed to cooperate in collecting statistical information 
on social protection programs in the Asia and Pacific region and in organizing events in the 
region. Data on social protection expenditure and recipients, compatible with the ILO Social 
Security Inquiry, the OECD Social Expenditure database, and the ADB Social Protection Index, 
will be collected. The three organizations have also agreed to cooperate in (i) organizing and 
analyzing data for monitoring social protection in each country; (ii) strengthening the capacity of 
government agencies in selected DMCs, particularly their officials, to collect and harmonize the 
data; and (iii) disseminating the data and the outcomes of this collaboration through appropriate 
means (online database, conferences, publications). A letter of agreement outlining the roles 
and responsibilities of each party to the collaboration and other arrangements will be signed 
before the TA is implemented.8  
 
27.  Progress will be monitored against intended outcomes and the output reflected in the 
attached design and monitoring framework and will involve preparing progress and completion 
reports. This will be undertaken by RSGS staff. 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION  
28.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) ADB 
administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 to be 
financed on a grant basis by the Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund, 
and (ii) ADB providing the balance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis, 
for Updating and Improving the Social Protection Index, and hereby reports this action to the 
Board. 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.  
                                                 
8  A draft agreement was discussed among ADB, ILO, and OECD at the technical meeting on SPI on 6–7 July 2010 
in Manila. The agreement is being reviewed by counsels from each organization.

10   Appendix 3 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
1.  A team of two international consultants (total of 8.5 person-months) will form the core 
technical team. They will be supported by national consultants from 31 countries. All consultants 
will  be  selected  and  hired  individually  according  to  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB) 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The specific 
technical tasks of each consultant are outlined here. 
A.  International Consultants 
1.  Social Protection Specialist and Team Leader (5 person-months) 
2.  The expert will have a graduate degree in sociology, economics, or a related area, and 
at least 7 years’ experience in social protection research or administration. The team leader will 
do the following: 
(i)  Coordinate and guide the national consultants, with help from the statistician. 
(ii)  Advise the national consultants and help them identify and validate information 
on social protection schemes and implement the improved methods developed 
under ADB technical assistance.1 
(iii)  Analyze the country reports prepared by the national consultants and suggest 
ways of improving them, if necessary. 
(iv)  In collaboration with the statistician, prepare the multi-country report. 
(v)  Contribute to the final report, including the analysis of findings and conclusions. 
(vi)  Assist RSGS in implementing Component 2: Capacity Development for Selected 
DMCs, including conduct of trainings and workshops. 
(vii)  Assist RSGS in conducting country and regional workshops. 
(viii)  In collaboration with the statistician, prepare the final report, including a draft 
index for all participating countries, social protection statistics, comparison of 
social  protection  arrangements,  analysis  of  findings  and  conclusions,  and 
suggestions for updating the SPI and making it sustainable. 
(ix)  Develop and implement a communications and dissemination plan. 
2.  Statistician (specializing in social sector statistics) (3.5 person-months) 
3.  The expert will have a graduate degree in mathematics, statistics, sociology, economics, 
or a related area, and at least 10 years’ experience in research or consulting in social protection 
statistics. The statistician will do the following: 
(i)  Help the team leader coordinate and guide the national consultants. 
(ii)  Coordinate and guide the national consultants in data collection and reporting 
according to the methods, formats, and handbook developed under ADB TA 
(footnote 1). 
(iii)  Help the national consultants present the data collection and reporting methods 
to the line ministries and statistical offices of the countries participating in the TA, 
through feedback and presentation documents. 
(iv)  Identify further data improvement needs and measures. 
(v)  Function as a help desk for national consultants.

B.  National Consultants and Researchers 
1.  Social Protection Specialists (31 specialists, 1.5 person-months each) 
 
4.  The experts will have a university degree in sociology, economics, statistics, or a related 
area, and at least 7 years’ experience in social protection research or administration. The 
consultant will do the following: 
(i)  Follow the handbook on the elaboration of social protection studies and the 
Social Protection Index (SPI) provided by ADB. 
(ii)  Visit relevant institutions and stakeholders and collect data and information on 
social  protection  arrangements,  legislation,  and  institutions,  according  to  the 
handbook. 
(iii)  Assess the country’s definition of social protection. 
(iv)  If necessary, organize a workshop with stakeholders. 
(v)  Coordinate  with  the  international  consultants  in  charge  of  combining  and 
monitoring  the  results  of  the  country  studies.  Follow  their  guidance  and 
comments. 
(vi)  Write a country report following the proposed structure. 
2.  Social Protection Officer (12 person-months) 
5.  This national consultant will have a university degree in sociology, economics, statistics, 
or  related  area,  and  at  least  7  years’  experience  in  research  or  administration  in  social 
protection. The consultant will do the following: 
(i)  Coordinate with and monitor national consultants from the 31 countries in the 
conduct and submission of country studies on social protection.  
(ii)  Assess the quality of the country reports and the data gathered. Provide advice 
to improve data quality, data validation, comparability of data among countries, 
and data analysis. 
(iii)  Help develop the SPI database by consolidating all country data, clean up the 
data and information, and help set up the SPI database.
